data.title: Intellisense filters

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 home 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create or edit an css file
2. inside an selector, type wid and hit tab
3. widows will be inserted

I never use widows. It annoys me its in intellisense.
I just want width inserted. 
I suggest to add an filter option which can exclude items from intellisense like files can be excluded.

My format suggestion:
```json
css.intellisenseExclude [
  "widows"
]
```

for html it would be something like
```json
html.intellisenseExclude [
  "font",
  "header[force-refresh-image]",
  "*[force-refresh-image]"
]
```

related: #12986

data.title: Question: How do I remove `Microsoft` folder from my `$HOME`?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Every time I start vscode this directory structure is being created inside my home folder:
```
~/Microsoft $ tree
.
└── TypeScript
    ├── node_modules
    │   └── types-registry
    │       ├── index.json
    │       ├── package.json
    │       └── README.md
    └── package.json

3 directories, 4 files
```

How do I change it's path, so it will be created somewhere else, or how do I prevent it from being created at all?
It ruins alignment of my other folders inside $HOME, and makes me feel uneasy.

data.title: Suggestion - searching source for constants.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Please consider adding an ability to search all files for constants (for whatever language we're using). Currently Visual Studio (nor VS Code) have this.

The goal here is to:
* Search for constant strings, ints, floats etc.
* Right click a constant in the source and offer "Find all references".

This is a gap in the tools, but would be very helpful especially for large legacy solutions where lots of hard coding may have crept in.

We can use Find in Files but this is crude and not able to distinguish true constants in the language from comments or identifier names.

e.g. find all constants "TestUser" would find all ocurrences of that string (but not var TestUser = ... and so on).

Under the hood a constant (in the language like say C#) is more or less a reference to something and so I suppose the Roslyn code could do this.

Thanks

data.title: Feedbacks about the paths autocomplete (v 1.8)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8

Hey guys! I had a discussion on Hacker News with @mjbvz about this new feature.

I think the feature could be improved by copying what the extension [Path Intellisense](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=christian-kohler.path-intellisense) provides.

Some screenshots will speak for themselves. 

Here is the extension:

![screen shot 2016-12-15 at 11 20 11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/591804/21234914/3e11a10e-c2ba-11e6-8e85-1b0d94a5299f.png)

![screen shot 2016-12-15 at 11 20 22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/591804/21234917/41bcbd34-c2ba-11e6-91ae-5feec9f62ce1.png)

I didn't look at the code but I would bet that they detect when a string starts with `'./'` or `'../'` and then list the files and folders in the current or previous directory.

**IMO it's perfect and it's exactly what I expect from a paths autocomplete.**

For comparison, here is the native feature:

![screen shot 2016-12-15 at 11 21 11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/591804/21234921/44982bb0-c2ba-11e6-9182-d19daee0d5a2.png)

![screen shot 2016-12-15 at 11 24 41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/591804/21234925/46be00d6-c2ba-11e6-9925-353f34f36cd8.png)

![screen shot 2016-12-15 at 11 24 47](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/591804/21234927/4897d030-c2ba-11e6-8074-cec1030b8401.png)

My thoughts:

1) **Intellisense suggests a lot of things (paths, snippets, symbols in the current file, etc)!**

On this screenshot, the file contains few lines of code (it's the `./index.js` of the project) so the list of suggestions is relatively small. But I tried in another project, in a file with 300 LOC and a lot of symbols, and the list of suggestions was really too long.

The suggestion I was looking for was `components` which is the first folder of the project in alphabetical order. When I started typing, `components` was not in the first visible suggestions. Actually I had to type almost the full name of the folder, i.e. `'./compon'`, to get the suggestion.

2) **The 🔧  icon is not really intuitive.**

The extension uses a file icon. You could display a folder ( 📁 ) or a file ( 📄 ) in function of the suggestion.

--- 

Hope these feedbacks can help.

Thanks for the amazing work! 🙂

data.title: Add setting to limit quick open results to current opened folder
data.body: Right now, quick open (Command/Ctrl P) searches outside the currently opened folder for files.  Due to the number and size of the projects I work on, QuickOpen often finds files outside the current folder I'm working in.  It would be nice to have a setting to limit quick open to the currently open folder.

data.title: SnippetString escaping doesn't work as documented for opening braces
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8
- OS Version: Windows 10

Let's say I want to complete the string (literally): `some text with $0 ${0:stuff} and \ LOL`. According to [the snippet docs](http://code.visualstudio.com/docs/customization/userdefinedsnippets#_creating-your-own-snippets), we should escape `$`, `{` and `}` with backslashes. In order to do this in a literal string, we need to use double-backslashes (to avoid the following characters being interpreted as control characters), so we have this:

```ts
completion.insertText = new SnippetString("some text with \\$0 \\$\\{0:stuff\\} and \\ LOL");
```

However, if you commit this completion, you will end up with:

```text
some text with $0 $\{0:stuff} and \ LOL
```

I believe the first backslash (before the opening brace) should not have appeared.

data.title: [folding] Collapsed block should expand if match found with addSelectionToNextFindMatch
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.8.0 (1.8.0)
- OS Version: 10.10.5 (14F1912)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have a Javascript file (although I guess it applies to all types) with a few methods and enough code  to exceed screen/viewport height.
2. In these methods, have a common variable name (`index` for example)
3. Collapse methods that are not the ones in use.
4. Use the keyboard shortcut associated with `editor.action.addSelectionToNextFindMatch` (`cmd+d` by default on Mac)
5. See the editor struggle (jumping screen) when matching a value in a collapsed block.

Expected behavior:
Collapsed block should expand to show selection, rather than remaining collapsed and have the cursor jump randomly in file.

data.title: Suboptimal hotkey workflow for "find in files"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.2

First of all, I love this editor, it's making me switch away from Sublime and vim.

However, working on a very large code base (the Linux kernel), I have a workflow that is suboptimal. I heavily rely on the "find in files" feature, as the C/C++ intellisense can't go far enough to solve all the things I usually look for (think: nested macros and such), which is totally ok.

So, this is my typical workflow:

1) CMD+Shift+F, enter the text to search and press enter
2) I get many matches, and usually I need to scan through the matching occurrences (in preview mode in an editor) in order to fully understand the one I need (the line shown in the side bar is usually not enough). In Sublime (or vim), I can quickly open an editor showing the matching occurrences using F4/Shift-F4.

In Code, using the keyboard the two only options I can find are:

- In the search side bar, press "down" until I highlight a match, and then I can open the file pressing "enter". However, this makes me lose the focus in the side bar, so it becomes super inefficient if I want to switch to the next matching file.

- If, at the previous step, I press "space" instead of "enter", the file gets opened but I don't lose the focus, which is already much better, but less than ideal because to go to the next occurrence I still have to press first "down" twice and then "space" again, and the fact that it's not documented makes me a bit uncomfortable, as I heavily rely on this hotkey.

It seems like having hotkeys to jump to the next occurrence while in the side bar is definitely a common case for relatively power users. It's literally an operation I do hundreds of times a day, so every bit of efficiency I can gain is huge (and it's standard in Sublime and of course customizable in vim).

Thanks!

data.title: Debugging not working with v8 version 3.12.19.19
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Win 7 enterprise 64 bit
- Node Version: 6.5.0 (Also tested with 4.1.2 and 4.6.0)


Hello, I work at Everi Games and we are evaluating Visual Studio Code as an editor to replace Webstorm (We script games in Javascript on top of a C++ engine using v8). We like everything about it, but we can't seem to get debugging to work. We think that it is related to the version of v8 we are using but we currently aren't in a position where we can update v8. I've done some debugging and found where the error is occurring, but I'm not sure what I could do to fix it. Could someone on the VSCode team look at debugging with an older version of v8, preferably version 3.12.19.19 and see what could be done to allow debugging to work?

Code that is breaking with relevant variables expanded in watch:
![vscodebreaklocation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10749782/21233671/9e012940-c2b5-11e6-91e6-2890d5bc596a.png)

Log dump:
[VSCodeDebugLog.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/655304/VSCodeDebugLog.txt)

data.title: Inspect variables by hovering over variable names in debug mode no longer works
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install the _Debugger for Chrome_ addon
2. Set up launch.json

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch Chrome against localhost, with sourcemaps",
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "launch",
            "url": "http://localhost:8080",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "webRoot": "${workspaceRoot}"
        },
        {
            "name": "Attach to Chrome, with sourcemaps",
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 9222,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "webRoot": "${workspaceRoot}"
        }
    ]
}

```
3. Run application in debug mode, and set breakpoints
4. Execution pauses as expected, but you can no longer inspect variables by hovering over them (this used to work with version 1.7)

data.title: Hot exit does not preserve the Language mode for unsaved files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new file in VSCode and do not save it
2. Change the **Language Mode** to something other than **Plain Text**
3. Restart the editor with **Hot Exit** enabled.

The reopened **Untitled-1** tab will have Plain Text as Language, even though another one was selected previously.

data.title: JavaScript IntelliSense not working in 1.8.0
data.body:
With this latest update, Intellisense no longer works in the project I was working on prior to the update.  When attempting to invoke IS or when hovering over a symbol or variable in the project, all I see is "loading". Sometimes I will see the "configure excludes" message, but these are already configured and haven't changed since the update. This is a fairly large Node project with many sub-apps, but Intellisense always worked fine prior to the update. I checked a smaller project, and everything is working as expected there.

|html2jade|wmaurer|0.2.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Upgrade to 1.8.0 from 1.7.1
2. Open large Node/ReactJS project and attempt to use Intellisense.

data.title: Check improved telemetry
data.body: Follow up #15321

data.title: http://code.visualstudio.com site does not work in China
data.body:
- VSCode Version:any
- OS Version:any

Steps to Reproduce:

Try to download vs code from https://code.visualstudio.com/Download. 

Files fail to load:

Download:80 GET https://az416426.vo.msecnd.net/scripts/a/ai.0.js net::ERR_TIMED_OUTwindow.appInsights.config.instrumentationKey @ Download:80(anonymous function) @ Download:81
Download:251 GET https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=Microsoft&repo=vscode&type=star&count=true net::ERR_TIMED_OUT
Download:254 GET https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js net::ERR_CONNECTION_TIMED_OUT(anonymous function) @ Download:254(anonymous function) @ Download:254
Download:273 GET https://code.visualstudio.com/scripts/main.js net::ERR_TIMED_OUT
Download:272 GET https://code.visualstudio.com/scripts/vendor.js net::ERR_TIMED_OUT

This probably causes the shiny big blue download buttons to be completely useless.

Trying the link from here:
https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_7
that links to:
https://vscode-update.azurewebsites.net/1.7.1/linux-rpm-x64/stable

This will be pending for about 2 minutes and then fails (timeout). Is it possible to host vscode somewhere that can be accessed from China?

Not sure if China actually blocks it or because "uncle Internet" installed the infrastructure.
